facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 157 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINALAPPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 157 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment dated March 20, 1964 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 20 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 20, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Appeal No. 20 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant tried by Special Judge Anti-Corruption Lucknow for offences under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(d) Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried for offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  read with s. 5 1  d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act by special Judge, Anti- Corruption, Lucknow

facts.text: Special Judge convicted appellant by judgment dated January 8, 1962 and sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2,000, default one year RI.

anchor.surface_text: who by his judgment dated January 8, 1962 companyvicted the appellant and sentenced him to three years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000. In default for payment of fine the appellant

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench dismissed appeal by judgment dated March 20, 1964 and affirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, which dismissed the appeal by its judgment dated March 20, 1964 and affirmed the companyviction and sentence imposed by the Special Judge

facts.text: Appellant employed as Assistant Director Enforcement, Government of India, Ministry of Commerce at Kanpur dealing with cancellation of licences of cloth dealers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was employed as Assistant Director Enforce- ment, Government of India, Ministry of Commerce at Kanpur and used to deal with matters regarding the cancellation of licences of cloth dealers at Kanpur.

facts.text: Appellant received confidential letter dated August 30, 1951 from District Magistrate Kanpur on or about September 5, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On or about September 5, 1951 the appellant received a companyfidential letter dated August 30, 1951 from the District Magistrate, Kanpur.

facts.text: On September 5, 1951 appellant called Ram Lal Kapoor, legal adviser of New Victoria Mills Ltd., to his house and showed him the letter demanding Rs.30,000 bribe from Sidh Gopal via Kapoor to save licence.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date the appellant called one Ram Lal Kapoor who was the legal adviser of New Victoria Mills Ltd. at his house. The appellant showed him the letter of the District Magistrate and on the strength of that letter he demanded through Ram Lal Kapoor a bribe of Rs. 30,000 from Sidh Gopal

facts.text: Sidh Gopal was partner of various firms dealing in cloth suspected of black-marketing.

anchor.surface_text: for saving his licence from being cancelled. It appears that Sidh Gopal was a partner of various firms dealing in cloth and it was suspected that these firms were indulging in black-marketing in cloth.

facts.text: On September 9, 1951 Sidh Gopal came to appellant who demanded bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Sidh Gopal came to the appellant on September 9, 1951 to talk over the matter and the appellant made the same demand of bribe from him.

facts.text: On September 11, 1951 appellant agreed with Ram Lal Kapoor to receive Rs.10,000 as first instalment of bribe from Sidh Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1951, the appellant is alleged to have agreed with Ram Lal Kapoor to receive a sum of Rs. 10,000 as first instalment of the bribe from Sidh Gopal through Ram Lal Kapoor.

facts.text: On September 11, 1951 at about 8 p.m. appellant went to house of Ram Lal Kapoor and accepted Rs.10,000 in currency notes and a Than of long cloth undertaking to save Sidh Gopal's licence.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on September 11, 1951 at about 8 p.m. the appellant went to the house of Ram Lal Kapoor and accepted the bribe of Rs. 10,000 in currency numberes and also a Than of long cloth from the said Ram Lal Kapoor undertaking that in lieu thereof the appellant would number report against Sidh Gopal

facts.text: Raid prearranged with Satish Chander PW1, Onkar Singh PW2, District Magistrate, Senior Superintendent of Police at Ram Lal Kapoor's premises.

anchor.surface_text: A raid had been prearranged and the raiding party companysisting of Shri Satish Chander P.W. I and Shri Onkar Singh P.W. 2, the District Magistrate and the Senior Superintendent of Police respectively were lying in wait at the premises of Ram Lal Kapoor.

facts.text: At about 9:45 p.m. on September 11, 1951 raiding party searched appellant and recovered Rs.10,000 from his person.

anchor.surface_text: At about 9. 45 p.m. the appellant came out of the bungalow of Ram Lal Kapoor and on the agreed signal being given, the raiding party came and on search of the appellant an amount of Rs. 10,000 was found from his person.

facts.text: At recovery, appellant stated amount was loan for purchasing bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the recovery of the money the appellant made a statement that the amount received by him was as a loan as he wanted to purchase a bungalow.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: never negotiated bribe, falsely implicated due to prosecution of Bhola Nath of Ms Mannulal Sidh Gopal u/s 7 Essential Supplies Act and his arrest under Preventive Detention Act by DM.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that he never negotiated with Ram Lal Kapoor or Sidh Gopal regarding the bribe but the appellant had been falsely implicated because he had prosecuted one Bhola Nath of the firm of M s Mannulal Sidh Gopal under s. 7 of Essential Supplies Act and the District Magistrate had arrested Bhola Nath and kept him under detention under the powers companyferred by the Preventive Detention Act.

facts.text: Special Judge disbelieved appellant's case and held prosecution evidence established charges.

anchor.surface_text: In order to take revenge for the arrest of Bhola Nath, Sidh Gopal and Ram Lal Kapoor had companyspired together and falsely implicated the appellant. The Special Judge disbelieved the case of the appellant and held that the prosecution evidence sufficiently established the charges

facts.text: Allahabad High Court affirmed Special Judge's findings, rejected appellant's case, held Rs.10,000 was illegal gratification not loan.

anchor.surface_text: under S. 161, Indian Penal Code and S. 5 2  read with s. 5 1  d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act. The findings of the trial companyrt have been affirmed by the Allahabad High Court in appeal which also rejected the case of the appellant as untrue

facts.text: High Court found Ram Lal Kapoor unlikely to lend Rs.10,000 without formal document.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the High Court that Ram. Lal Kapoor was number likely to lend a sum of Rs. 10,000 to the appellant without getting a formal document executed.

facts.text: Appellant claimed executed hand-note or receipt for Rs.10,000 but High Court rejected.

anchor.surface_text: It is number suggested by the appellant that he executed a hand-note in favour of Ram Lal Kapoor. There was a suggestion that he granted a receipt for Rs. 10,000 to Ram Lal Kapoor but the High Court rejected the case of the appellant on this point.

facts.text: Appellant did not mention receipt immediately upon recovery, only later.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has observed that, in the first instance, the appellant did number make a statement with regard to the receipt as soon as the amount was recovered from him. It was only after he was taken to Marden Singhs place that he made a belated statement

facts.text: No panchanama prepared, no independent witness at search.

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended on behalf of the appellant that numberpanchanama was prepared by the District Magistrate or the Senior Superintendent of Police who recovered the money from the appellant. It was also stated that numberindependent witness

facts.text: District Magistrate related to Sidh Gopal.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the District Magistrate is related to Sidh Gopal

facts.text: Appellant received letter Ex.P-1 on September 5, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the appellant had received the letter of District Magistrate-Ex. P-1 on September 5, 1951

facts.text: Bhola Nath, salesman of Ms Mannulal Sidh Gopal, arrested in August 1951 on appellant's report.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, evidence in this case that Bhola Nath who was a Salesman of M s Mannulal Sidh Gopal was arrested in August, 1951 on the report of the appellant

issues.text: The first question for determination is whether a presumption under sub-s. 1 of S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act arises Where in any trial of an offence punishable under S. 161 or S. 165 of the Indian Penal Code it is proved that an accused person has accepted or obtained, or has agreed to accept or attempted or obtain, for himself or for any other person, any gratification other than legal remuneration or any valuable thing from any person, it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted or obtained, or agreed to accept or attempted to obtain, that gratification or that valuable thing, as the case may be, as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in the said S. 161, or as the case may be, without consideration or for a consideration which he knows to be inadequate.

holdings.text: In the circumstances of the present case, the requirements of sub-s. 1 of S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act have been fulfilled and the presumption thereunder must be raised.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that, in the circumstances of the present case, the requirements of sub-s.  1  of S. 4 have been fulfilled and the presumption thereunder must be raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proved accused accepted gratification other than legal remuneration; mere receipt sufficient per statutory text and precedents (Dhanvantrai Balwantrai Desai v. State of Maharashtra; C.I. Emden v. State of Uttar Pradesh).

holdings.text: The burden of proof lying upon the accused under s. 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act will be satisfied if the accused person establishes his case by a preponderance of probability and it is not necessary that he should establish his case by the test of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the burden of proof lying upon the accused under s. 4 1  of the Prevention of Corruption Act will be satisfied if the accused person establishes his case by a preponderance of probability and it is number necessary that he

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prosecution's beyond reasonable doubt standard; accused rebuts presumption by preponderance per common law principles and precedents (Woolmington v. Director of Public Prosecutions; Rex v. Carr-Briant; Harbhajan Singh v. State of Punjab).

holdings.text: The appellant has not proved his case by the test of preponderance of probability and the lower courts rightly reached the conclusion that the amount was taken by the appellant not as a loan but as illegal gratification.
